title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" allows for grants to states to implement quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families under the Social Security Act. The purpose of this section is to improve the well-being of children by establishing quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. States must submit a grant application that includes a description of the programs, intended outcomes, evidence of effectiveness, and results of a needs assessment. The statewide needs assessment for home visitation programs must include details on program quality, capacity, funding sources, gaps in services, and training activities. States must prioritize serving communities in high need when supporting these programs with funds provided under this section. Assurances from the State include prioritizing high-need communities for home visitation programs, reserving 5% of grant funds for training and technical assistance, promoting coordination with other services, and providing referrals when appropriate. The State must prioritize high-need communities for home visitation programs, reserve funds for training and technical assistance, coordinate with other services, provide referrals when appropriate, comply with specified requirements, and cooperate with evaluations. Indian tribes receive allotted funds based on the number of children in need within the tribe. The Secretary shall allot funds to States based on the number of children in need within the State whose families have income below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary allots funds to States based on the number of children in need with families below 200 percent of the poverty line. Reallotments are available if a State certifies unspent funds. States must maintain effort in quality home visitation programs to receive grants from the Secretary. The Secretary provides grants to States based on eligible expenditures, with a reimbursable percentage defined for each fiscal year. Eligible expenditures must meet certain requirements to receive the grant. The Secretary provides grants to States based on eligible expenditures for home visitation programs for families with young children. Eligible expenditures must adhere to evidence-based models, employ well-trained staff, and show strong organizational capacity. The program must employ competent staff, maintain high-quality supervision, establish linkages to community resources, and include expenditures for training and evaluations. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence of effectiveness. The program prioritizes funding based on evidence of effectiveness, with a decreasing applicable percentage for eligible expenditures in fiscal years 2010 to 2014. States receiving grants cannot use other federal funds for their share of costs, and there is waiver authority in place. The State receiving a grant under this section cannot use other federal funds to cover their share of costs. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify provisions for Indian tribes if it would impose an undue burden. States must submit annual reports on their progress in addressing the program's purposes. Each State receiving a grant under this section must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the services, characteristics of programs and providers, recipients of services, program costs, and outcomes experienced by recipients. The Secretary shall conduct an independent evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section to assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, development, school readiness, and community service connections. The Secretary will evaluate home visitation programs to assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, development, school readiness, and community service connections. Reports to Congress will be submitted within 2 years for an interim report and within 4 years for a final report. Annual reports to Congress will also be provided. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress on the evaluation of home visitation programs, including details on targeted communities, service delivery models, program characteristics, outcomes, and research-based components. The evaluation of home visitation programs includes details on families served, outcomes, research-based instruction, training provided, costs, and monitoring methods. Additionally, funds are reserved for evaluation costs, training, and technical assistance. The Secretary is appropriated funds for early childhood home visitation programs, including grants to Indian tribes. The allocated amounts are $100,000,000 for 2010, $250,000,000 for 2011, $400,000,000 for 2012, $550,000,000 for 2013, and $700,000,000 for 2014. Indian tribes are treated as States for the purposes of this section.
